quotes: Mathematics is the language in which God has written the universe. — Galileo Galilei
Pure mathematics is, in its way, the poetry of logical ideas. — Albert Einstein
Mathematics is not about numbers, equations, computations, or algorithms: it is about understanding. — William Paul Thurston
The essence of mathematics lies in its freedom. — Georg Cantor
Mathematics knows no races or geographic boundaries; for mathematics, the cultural world is one country. — David Hilbert
In mathematics, the art of proposing a question must be held of higher value than solving it. — Georg Cantor
Mathematics is the music of reason. — James Joseph Sylvester
God created the integers; all else is the work of man. — Leopold Kronecker
A mathematician is a device for turning coffee into theorems. — Paul Erdős
The mathematician does not study pure mathematics because it is useful; he studies it because he delights in it and he delights in it because it is beautiful. — Henri Poincaré
Mathematics compares the most diverse phenomena and discovers the secret analogies that unite them. — Joseph Fourier
To those who do not know mathematics it is difficult to get across a real feeling as to the beauty, the deepest beauty, of nature. — Richard Feynman
The study of mathematics, like the Nile, begins in minuteness but ends in magnificence. — Charles Caleb Colton
Mathematics is the queen of sciences and number theory is the queen of mathematics. — Carl Friedrich Gauss

Pure mathematics consists entirely of assertions to the effect that, if such and such a proposition is true of anything, then such and such another proposition is true of that thing. — Bertrand Russell
A mathematician who is not also something of a poet will never be a complete mathematician. — Karl Weierstrass
Mathematics may be defined as the subject in which we never know what we are talking about, nor whether what we are saying is true. — Bertrand Russell
There is no inquiry which is not finally reducible to a question of Numbers. — Auguste Comte
Go down deep enough into anything and you will find mathematics. — Dean Schlicter
Without mathematics, there's nothing you can do. Everything around you is mathematics. Everything around you is numbers. — Shakuntala Devi
Number rules the universe. — Pythagoras
Mathematics is the most beautiful and most powerful creation of the human spirit. — Stefan Banach
If I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of Giants. — Isaac Newton
The laws of nature are but the mathematical thoughts of God. — Euclid
Life is good for only two things, discovering mathematics and teaching mathematics. — Siméon Poisson
As far as the laws of mathematics refer to reality, they are not certain; and as far as they are certain, they do not refer to reality. — Albert Einstein
Mathematics is the art of giving the same name to different things. — Henri Poincaré
In mathematics, you don't understand things. You just get used to them. — John von Neumann
Do not worry about your difficulties in mathematics. I can assure you mine are still greater. — Albert Einstein
Arithmetic is where numbers fly like pigeons in and out of your head. — Carl Sandburg
Mathematics is concerned with all types of formal, logical relations. — Hermann Weyl
Logic is the anatomy of thought. — John Locke
Mathematics is the science of patterns, and nature exploits just about every pattern that there is. — Ian Stewart
The only way to learn mathematics is to do mathematics. — Paul Halmos
Mathematicians are like Frenchmen: whatever you say to them they translate into their own language and forthwith it is something entirely different. — Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
An expert is someone who has made all the mistakes that can be made in a very narrow field. — Niels Bohr
How can it be that mathematics, being after all a product of human thought independent of experience, is so admirably adapted to the objects of reality? — Albert Einstein
If people do not believe that mathematics is simple, it is only because they do not realize how complicated life is. — John von Neumann
The book of nature is written in the language of mathematics. — Galileo Galilei
Mathematics possesses not only truth, but supreme beauty — a beauty cold and austere, like that of sculpture. — Bertrand Russell
